results.title: The Golden Jubilee of the CRB: Victoria 1913-1963
results.creator_credit: Jim Stirling and Country Roads Board
results.brief_description: Depicts 50 years of progress in road and bridge construction in Victoria. The first survey made in 1913 showed that travel was hazardous on the hand-made roads. In 1916 the first all-weather road to Geelong was completed. Gradually isolated settlers and mailmen were able to travel in the country. Municipal co-operation was sought and aid given for road construction by machines. Recent work includes new concrete bridges, and the completion of a two-lane highway from Melbourne to Dandenong, all important to Victoria’s prosperity. During 50 years, motor registrations increased from 10,000 to 90,000.

results.title: Click go the shears
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Link Films
results.brief_description: A highly stylised humorous treatment of the famous Australian ballad, using a minimum of animation. Sung by Cedric McLaughlin and the Link Singers.

results.title: Beyond the boom: metal mining in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle, Australian Mining Industry Council and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The evolution of mining in Australia from the first gold discoveries to the iron, nickel and copper developments of the 1960’s , its historic importance in national growth and economic stability and in the exploration and settling of much of Australia. The scope of modern mining and processing industries, exploration and prospecting, the growth of new towns and stimulation of regional development.

results.title: Australia's art of the Dreamtime: Quinkin country
results.creator_credit: Jim Needham and WIPB-TV, Ball State University
results.brief_description:
A documentary on the history of Australian First Nations peoples and their rock art in the Cape York Peninsula region of Queensland. The program explores not only the historical background of the rock paintings but theorises on the first arrival of First Nations peoples to this land and the formation of the landscape itself through archaeological, geological and palaeontological evidence.
During the 1950s Australian artist and author Percy Trezise went on a quest to locate the rock art around Laura in the Cape York region and through contact with First Nations elders and befriending First Nations writer, Dick Roughsey, he was eventually accepted as a “tribal brother”. In this program, Percy, using images from his own paintings, interprets First Nations Dreamtime stories, mythology and initiation ceremonies as represented by the rock paintings. He speaks of his own experiences and respect for First Nations peoples, their culture and their heritage. Voice over narration by Chris Schenkel. Note: Visual quality average - filmed on video camera. Arts 2002 and SBS Independent.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 13
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew Mackenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant-garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew investigates ACMI (Australian Centre for the Moving Image) at Federation Square three weeks before its opening. Not only is the functionality and architecture discussed of ACMI’s new home, but Andrew, through interviews with Victoria Lyn and Alessio Cavallaro, also discovers ACMI’s history and its expanded role in the future world of the moving image through its innovative upcoming programs such as “Deep Space” and “Pathways”. This is followed by an in depth look at the “Kiss my Art” public program, a collaboration between shop traders and artists, curated by Antonia Chaffey. Shows interviews with Lissa Watt (artist - Club-X), Anne-Marie Power (artist - Franco Cozzo), Robyn Carretti, Roland Smith (video artist) and finishes off with a piece by video artist Angus Wyatt called “Success” from the “(trans)actions/(plat)forms for alterity” Exhibition at the Gertrude Contemporary Art Space.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 12
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew Mackenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant-garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew focuses on the 2002 Melbourne Art Fair which is held at the Royal Exhibition Buildings every two years. The Art Fair is a trading place for artists, galleries, collectors and lovers of art and not only features local artists and galleries but also includes international exhibitors from the US, UK, China, and New Zealand. The program features several interviews by Andrew including William Nuttall (Niagara Galleries), Brian Wallace (Red Gate Gallery, Beijing), Stuart Purves, Bronwyn Johnson, Christopher Hodges (Art Fair Board members), Anna Schwartz (Anna Schwartz Gallery), Martin Browne (Cohan Leslie and Browne, New York), and Alexie Glass (ACMI). Also includes examples of art works available for sale at the Fair.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 11
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie deviates from the program’s usual format to incorporate an in-depth interview with English artist, art critic, writer and television producer, Matthew Collings on the eve of his Australian lecture tour, 2002. Collings provides a refreshing and challenging outlook on contemporary art and provides contextual observation on contemporary art values and practice. Collings is best known for the BBC series ‘This is Modern Art’ and his book ‘Crazy Nation’ amongst others. Screen Talk this week looks at the work of Geneine Honey and includes an interview with excerpts from ‘Young Sad Love’ and ‘Don’t Go Out Walking’.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 10
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie interviews Juliana Enberg, director of the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art (ACCA) at the opening of it’s new building at Southbank and inaugural exhibition by Susan Norrie ‘A History of Happiness’. The American artist Steve Keene exhibits his latest work at Linden gallery with the claim as being ‘the most prolific artist in America’. His work pokes fun at the age of “mechanical” reproduction and technologically driven work. Sandra Bridie, artist in residence at Tower Studio discusses her project ‘6 Contextual Modules’ and discusses her ongoing solo practise where Bridie presents herself as a multiple of fictional artists. Dominic Lococo discusses F4, a new multi-media space. Screen Talk: Brendan Lee discusses “Projekt”, the first quarterly journal in VHS format and presents excerpts including ‘Test’ by Sanja Pahoki, ‘The Bong Relay Business’ by TV Moore and ‘Container’ by Stephen Honeggar and Anthony Hunt.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 09
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. Andrew MacKenzie in this episode introduces the annual Experimenta exhibition held at Southgate, ‘Prototype’. Artists in the exhibition include: Stephen Barras (Op Shop), Richard Brown (Mimetic Starfish), Jane Crappsley, Chris Henschke, Isobel Knowles, Hama Marriott, Ben Morieson (Burnout 2001 - Part 1 - The game), Iain Mott, Marc Raszewski, Jim Sosnin, Bruce Mowson (Flesh Antenna), Simon Morton, Martin Walch, Amy Youngs, Christopher Mether, Elizabeth Vander Zaag. Screen Talk looks at the video work of Kate Just who discusses her motivations, comic relief and the spontaneous nature of her work. Excerpts of video work include: ‘Home alone’, ‘Marsha’, ‘Needle exchange’ and ‘Beat bag baby’.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 08
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. This episode first up visits Jawbone Wetlands Nature Reserve to look at the source of inspiration of Caroline Oxley’s exhibition of paintings ‘Return To Jawbone’, exhibited at Fitzroy Gallery. Kathy Temin in ‘Kylie Night’ explores her ongoing fascination with the pop-princess-phenomenon of Kylie Minogue and the culture of identity fetishism. Collaborators Christos Linou and Robert Mangion interweave the disciplines of performance, visual arts and film making to perform and exhibit the third part of their series of work ‘The Act Of Being Inside Out’ at Mass Gallery and the County Court in Melbourne. Curated by Stuart Koop at Monash University Museum of Art is the group show ‘Gulliver’s Travels’ that seeks to explore the recent popularity of model making and the miniature in Australian art. The exhibition includes: Craige Andre, Matt Calvert, Richard Giblett, Callum Morton, Louise Paramor, Ricky Swallow and Tim Silver. Screen Talk shows an excerpt from ‘S-Crash’ by Lindsay Cox and Victor Holder.

description_for_label: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. This episode first up visits Jawbone Wetlands Nature Reserve to look at the source of inspiration of Caroline Oxley’s exhibition of paintings ‘Return To Jawbone’, exhibited at Fitzroy Gallery. Kathy Temin in ‘Kylie Night’ explores her ongoing fascination with the pop-princess-phenomenon of Kylie Minogue and the culture of identity fetishism. Collaborators Christos Linou and Robert Mangion interweave the disciplines of performance, visual arts and film making to perform and exhibit the third part of their series of work ‘The Act Of Being Inside Out’ at Mass Gallery and the County Court in Melbourne. Curated by Stuart Koop at Monash University Museum of Art is the group show ‘Gulliver’s Travels’ that seeks to explore the recent popularity of model making and the miniature in Australian art. The exhibition includes: Craige Andre, Matt Calvert, Richard Giblett, Callum Morton, Louise Paramor, Ricky Swallow and Tim Silver. Screen Talk shows an excerpt from ‘S-Crash’ by Lindsay Cox and Victor Holder.
